Kids' rights are at risk because Connecticut doesn't have a law to limit searches of students' cellphones in school. Tell your legislators to pass H.B. 5170, a bill to protect students' privacy.
  

Protect students' privacy rights

Tell your legislators to pass H.B. 5170 now.

Dear ##first_name[Supporter]##,

Students don't check their rights at the schoolhouse door. But some Connecticut schools have policies that claim students have no expectation of privacy in school. These policies allow staff to take a student's phone without reason, search the phone without looking for something specific, find a school policy violation, and suspend a child on the spot, refer the child for expulsion or, even call the police. This risks students' rights and can fuel the school-to-prison pipeline, a pipeline that disproportionately hurts youth of color.

Connecticut must act to protect students' privacy rights. Tell your legislators to pass H.B. 5170.

H.B. 5170 would protect students' rights by preventing school staff from taking or searching a student's personal cellphone unless they suspect there is evidence of a school policy violation or risk of imminent personal injury. This would bring Connecticut in line with the U.S. Supreme Court's decision that before searching a student, school staff need a specific, articulable reason to believe the student has broken a law or school rule.

Students' rights can't wait. Tell your state legislators to pass H.B. 5170 now.

There are only a few weeks left in Connecticut's legislative session. If legislators don't protect students' rights this year, kids will be going back to school next year without their privacy rights explicitly protected by state law.

Thank you for standing with civil liberties,

David McGuire
Executive Director
ACLU of Connecticut
